Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of naked woman (Isis-Hathor?). Her hands are free from her body and modelled in the round. Solid, mould-made, with modifications using a sharp tool. Now missing head, arms and legs. Red-brown Nile silt, with abundant fine gold mica, quartz and some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar piece, but different mould series, dated to the Ptolemaic period in the Petrie Museum (UC48406). Similar 4th to 3rd century BC or early Ptolemaic solid Hathor figures, depicting a nude female with arms flush against her body, are known from Tanis (Brissaud 1994,15, fig. 1b), Ras el-Soda, Alexandria (Adriani 1952, pl. 14, 1), Gabbari, Alexandria (Kassab Tezgör 2001, 421, fig. 12.14), and unprovenanced (Fischer 1994, no. 806; Fischer 1995, pl. 44, 1; Vogt 1924, pl. xci, 6; Török 1995, no. 210; Fischer 1994, 75n. 25 and 329: no. 807). Parallels from Edfu (Henne 1925, pl. 28, 9) and Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl. 35, 9, Petrie Museum UC33573) are not given specific dates. '1885' is written on this piece in pencil. Adriani, A. 1952, Municipalité d’Alexandrie, Annuaire du Musée Gréco-Romain. Volume III (1940-1950), Alexandria. Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. LiebieghausMuseum Alter Plastik.
